newsitem.title: USA: PG&E lists four gas-fired plants to be sold.
newsitem.headline: PG&E lists four gas-fired plants to be sold.

text.p: Pacific Gas and Electric Co (PG&E) has decided which four power plants it will sell to meet state regulators' requirements that it divest 50 percent of its fossil-fueled generation assets, a company spokesman said Tuesday.
The California natural-gas fired power plants are Hunter's Point in San Francisco, Morro Bay near San Luis Obispo, Moss Landing near Monterey and a plant in Oakland, said spokesman Tony Ledwell.
The four units have a book value of $400 million.
PG&E would still own three fossil-fueled power plants.
The divested plants represent half of PG&E's total fossil-fueled generation capacity of around 6,300 MW, the company said.

In addition to fossil-fueled generation, PG&E owns and operates 114 hydroelectric units and 14 geothermal units with a combined capacity of nearly 5,200 MW and the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant with a capacity of just over 2,000 MW.
Potential buyers for the gas-fired plants have not yet been identified, Ledwell said.
PG&E will file a final plan for divestiture with the California Public Utilities Commission in mid-November, he added.
